keyTakeAways: The internet's reliance on a few major cloud providers, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS), makes it vulnerable to outages, even if brief.
The root cause of the outage was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing access to data stored in AWS services like DynamoDB and EC2.
Historical outages—such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software bug and AT&T’s 11-hour network failure—show a pattern of cascading failures in critical systems.
Experts warn that the concentration of services in a few cloud regions undermines the internet’s original decentralized and resilient design.
AWS has experienced major disruptions infrequently, with the last one in 2021, but the impact of each event is significant due to widespread dependency.
The outage demonstrates the need for redundancy and competition among cloud providers to reduce systemic risk.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) on Monday, October 20, 2025, disrupted thousands of online services worldwide, including banking, social media, airline booking, and e-commerce platforms. The root cause was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), which prevented access to data in AWS services like DynamoDB and EC2. Although AWS is generally reliable, experts warn that the internet's heavy dependence on a small number of cloud providers makes the system vulnerable to cascading outages. Historical events, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software glitch and AT&T’s network failures, illustrate a recurring pattern of systemic fragility. Experts stress that without greater redundancy and competitive cloud services, the internet remains fragile, despite its scale and ubiquity.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
